loans.name: Maria

texts.es: María tiene la edad  de 33 años, está casada, vive con el esposo y tres hijos. Con su crédito pretende hacer la compra de fertilizantes, fungicidas y pagar mano de obra para hacerse un vivero de hortalizas y luego venderla en los supermercados. Con estas mejoras al cultivo espera obtener un poco de ganancias y así mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia y también invertir un poco más en el área de cultivo y también cumplir algunas metas.  Es el primer  préstamo que  recibido de FUDECOSUR. Élla no había tenido antes otros préstamos en bancos estatales, pero FUDECOSUR le ha brindado el préstamo con mayores facilidades y la tasa de intereses mucho más baja.
texts.en: María is 33 years old. She is married and lives with her husband and three children. With her loan, she intends to buy fertilizers and fungicides and pay for labor to create a nursery for vegetables, which she will later sell to the supermarkets. With these improvements to her crops, she hopes to obtain a little profit and thus improve her family's living conditions. She will also invest a little more in her cultivation area and also reach some goals. This is the first loan she has received from FUDECOSUR. She has not had previous loans from state banks. FUDECOSUR provided the loan with better terms and a much lower interest rate.

loans.use: to buy supplies to grow vegetables.

location.town: Bello Oriente, Agua Buena, Coto Brus

loans.name: Elsa Diner

texts.es:
La señora  Elsa de 37 años de edad es madre soltera se dedica a la venta de Alfarería como ser, gallos con forma de  cantaros,  Jarrones etc. tiene una hija que depende de ella y vive en  casa propia ubicada en una  comunidad de San Lorenzo al sur de Honduras.
Doña Elsa tiene de dedicarse a su negocio 17 años y también se dedica a la venta de ropa nueva,  sus ventas son turistas que pasan por la zona y comerciantes, que compran sus adornos de barro.
Doña Elsa con el apoyo de este préstamo espera invertirlo en un la compra de ropa nueva como blusas, faldas, vestidos, camisas, pantalones, etc. Para su segundo negocio y así tener mercadería para la venta en la temporada navideña que es cuando más vende este tipo de mercadería, desea que esta inversión le permita mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
Doña Elsa uno de sus sueños es poder remodelar su casa.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Diciembre del 2014.
texts.en:
Elsa is 37 years old, she is a single mother who works selling pottery such as jugs in the form of chickens. she has a daughter who is dependent on her and lives in her own house in the community of San Lorenzo in the south of Honduras.

Elsa has worked in her business for 17 years. she also sells new clothing. She sells to tourists passing through the area and also to businesses who buy her clay decorations. With this loan Elsa hope to invest in buying new clothing like blouses, skirts, shirts, dresses, pants, etc. for her second business. Then she will have merchandise to sell for the Christmas season which is when she sells this type of merchandise the most. She hopes that this investment will allow her to improve her quality of living and that of her family. Elsa's dream is to renovate her house.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - December 2014.

loans.use: to buy blouses, skirts, dresses, shirts, pants, etc for her other business.

loans.name: Geiner

texts.es: Geiner tiene la edad  de 42 años, está casado, vive con la esposa y dos hijos. Con su crédito pretende hacer la compra de fertilizantes, fungicidas y pagar mano de obra en trabajos de asistencia para el café, además de comprar algunas plantas de almácigo para hacer resiembras a inicio de lluvias esto con el objetivo de aumentar la densidad de plantas por área, además de aprovechar la buena fertilidad del suelo y las condiciones de clima y otras que favorecen al cultivo de café. Con estas mejoras al cultivo espera obtener un poco de ganancias y así mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia y también invertir un poco más en el área de cultivo y también cumplir algunas metas.  Es el primer  préstamo que  recibido de FUDECOSUR. Él no había tenido antes otros préstamos en bancos estatales, pero FUDECOSUR le ha brindado el préstamo con mayores facilidades y la tasa de intereses mucho más baja.
texts.en:
Geiner is 42 years old, married, and lives with his wife and their two children.  With this loan, he hopes to purchase fertilizers, fungicides, and to pay laborers to help with his coffee crop.  He will also purchase seedlings to be transplanted at the start of the rainy season.  His goal is to increase the density of his plants to take advantage of the fertile soil and climate conditions that favor coffee growing.  With these improvements, he hopes to see profits from his crop so that he can improve his family's living conditions, invest a little more in his fields, and also achieve other goals.  

This is the first loan he has received from FUDECOSUR.  He has not taken other loans from state banks, but FUDECOSUR provided him a loan with good terms and a much lower interest rate.

loans.use: to purchase supplies and seedlings.

location.town: El Ceibo, San Vito, Coto Brus

loans.name: Miguel Angel

texts.es: Miguel es un hombre trabajador que se gana la vida con su trabajo en una empresa cercana, pero además los fines de semana se gana la vida reparando aparatos electrónicos actividad que realiza desde hace 9 años en su vivienda, por lo que no necesita pagar local para su pequeño taller electrónico. Él vive con su esposa y su grupo familiar en vivienda propia desde hace 9 años. Miguel desea mejorar sus servicios invirtiendo en repuestos y herramientas para realizar su trabajo, por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: repuestos electrónicos y herramientas para ofrecer un mejor servicio a sus clientes que tanta confianza depositan en él.
texts.en: Miguel is a hard-working man who earns his living with his work in a nearby business, but in addition, on the weekends he earns his living repairing electronics, work that he has done for 9 years in his home, so is not necessary to pay for a retail location for his small electronics repair shop. He has lived with his wife and their family in his own house for 9 years. Miguel wants to improve his services, investing in parts and tools to do his work, so he has asked FUSAI for a loan to invest in electronics parts and tools to offer better service to his customers who put all their confidence in him.

loans.use: to invest in electrical parts and tools.

loans.name: Navruzahon

texts.ru: Наврузахон 24 года, замужем, мать 2 детей дошкольного возраста. У Наврузахон среднее образование, она занимается полеводством. На сегодняшний день в хозяйстве Наврузахон есть 0,14 ГА земли. В прошлом году Наврузахон построила теплицу и получала хороший урожай, реализуя экологически чистые помидоры и капусту. На полученную прибыль Наврузахон построила еще одну теплицу. Ежемесячный совокупный доход Наврузахон составляет около 15,000 сом (KGS).  Она обратилась в Банк «Бай – Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 60,000 сом (KGS) на покупку семян помидор, минеральных удобрений и клеенки для теплицы. Наврузахон планирует удвоить свою прибыль, и накопить средства на постройку еще одной теплицы.
texts.en: Navruzahon is 24 years old, married and a mother of 2 preschool-age children. Navruzahon has a secondary education and is involved in farming. Today her farm consists of 0.14 hectares of land. Last year, Navruzahon built a greenhouse and received a good harvest, selling ecologically-clean tomatoes and cabbage. Navruzahon used the profits to build another greenhouse. Her combined monthly income amounts to about 15,000 som (KGS). She requested a loan in the amount of 60,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum" Bank to buy tomato seeds, mineral fertilizers and plastic for her greenhouses. Navruzahon plans to double her profit and save money to build another greenhouse.

loans.use: to buy tomato seeds, mineral fertilizers and plastic for her greenhouses

loans.name: Auwalu

texts.en: Auwalu is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Auwalu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Auwalu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked about his goals, Auwalu expressed a desire to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for his family, and in the long run, move to the city with his family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing for his family, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es: Gracias a su primer financiamiento Francisca compro los insumos necesarios para dar asistencia y mantenimiento a sus cultivos de hortalizas de las cuales obtuvo una buena producción y una excelente cosecha de muy buena calidad la cual asistió adecuadamente evitando esta pudiese haberse dañado con una enfermedad o un deterioro mediante el factor clima. Con el financiamiento brindado gracias a los diferentes inversionistas con los fondos KIVA en alianza con la cooperativa COMIXMUL compro abono, foliares, fertilizantes pago mano de obra calificada para dar una mejor asistencia y mantenimiento a sus cultivos ayudando a mantener el producto limpio y sano vendiendo el mismo a muy buen precio y obteniendo excelentes ganancias. Actualmente Francisca por segunda ocasión está nuevamente solicitando un segundo crédito el cual nuevamente invertirá pero esta vez lo orientara a sus cultivos de café ya que gracias al mismo ella puede cada cosecha mejorar la calidad del grano, ampliar mediante la compra de más plantilla de café y crecer con su negocio por lo cual espera nuevamente ser apoyada para salir adelante.
texts.en:
Thanks to her first loan, Francisca purchased the supplies necessary to support and maintain her vegetable crops which had a good production and an excellent harvest of very good quality, which helped her enough. Without this, it could have been damaged by a disease or deterioration due to the weather. With the loan offered, thanks to the different investors with the Kiva funds in alliance with the COMIXMUL cooperative, she purchased manure, foliant fertilizer, fertilizers, and paid skilled labor costs to provide better care and maintenance to her crops, helping to keep the product clean and healthy and selling it at a very good price, getting excellent earnings.

Currently, Francisca for the second time, is asking for a second loan which she will again invest, but this time she will focus on her coffee crop since thanks to it, she can harvest a better quality of bean each time, increase it through the purchase of more coffee plants and grow with her business so she hopes to again be supported to get ahead.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural supplies to help her coffee crops in this new season.

loans.name: Guillerma

texts.en:
Guillerma is 46 years old and married. She has four children, 2 of whom are in school.  

Guillerma is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 14,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs. She has been raising pigs for two years now, and has borrowed 4 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Guillerma would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora works hard to support her family. She has a business selling roasted whole pig in the Philippines.

Leonora has requested a PHP 19,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients, pigs and other materials for her business. She has been in this business for 12 years now.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

In the future, Leonora would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients, pigs and other materials for her business

loans.name: Mirna Guadalupe

texts.es: Mirna tiene 41 años de edad y habita en casa propia junto a su compañero de vida y su hija de 17 años de edad. Mirna se gana a vida por medio de la venta de frutas y verduras desde hace mucho tiempo. De esta forma se gana la vida y lleva el sustento a su hogar. La venta la realiza de forma ambulante y este negocio es su principal fuente de ingresos por lo que solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la compra de variedad de verduras y frutas (papas, tomates, cebollas, plátanos, aguacates, sandias, etc.) espera poder contar con este financiamiento y así poder aumentar sus ventas e ingresos.
texts.en: Mirna, 41, lives in her own home with her partner and daughter who is 17. Mirna has earned a living by selling fruit and vegetables for a long time. Through this job, she makes enough money to live and take food home. Her business is mobile and as this is her main source of income, she is asking FUSAI for a loan to invest in the purchase of a variety of fruit and vegetables (potatoes, tomatoes, onions, bananas, avocados, watermelons, etc.) and hopes that it will increase her sales and revenue.

loans.use: to buy potatoes, tomatoes, onions, bananas, avocados, watermelons, etc.

loans.name: Maria Magdalena

texts.es: Maria de 34 años de edad es madre soltera vive en casa propia con sus dos hijas, ella se dedica a la venta de frutas y verduras, ella quiere mejorar su vivienda cambiando el techo que muestra en la fotografía, pero con lo que obtiene de sus ventas no le alcanza para poder realizarlo, por esa razón solicita un crédito para la compra de laminas, polines y pago de mano de obra para que ella y sus hijas puedan vivir mas seguras.
texts.en: Maria, 34, is a single mother who lives in her own home with her two daughters. She sells fruit and vegetables for a living. She wants to improve her housing by changing the roof shown in the photograph, but she can not afford to do this just with her income from sales. For this reason, she is applying for a loan to purchase sheets, poles and to pay for the labor so that she and her daughters can live more safely.

loans.use: to buy sheets, poles and for the payment of labor.

loans.name: Tony's Group

texts.en:
Tony is 36 years old, has 4 children, and lives in Rabare C village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Tony works as a peasant farmer for a living. Where Tony lives, his family and his community do not have access to safe drinking water. The community collects their water from Kawilson well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. If Rabare C had a way to treat their water, they could improve the health of their community, keeping children at school and parents at work.

This is why Tony is requesting a loan for a chlorine dispenser on behalf of his community. Tony was elected to represent his community as a volunteer promoter. He is not only representing his community on Kiva, but also volunteers his time to educate the people in  Rabare C village on the importance of safe water, and how to use the chlorine dispenser when they come to fetch water at their local water point. The loan will be used for the installation of the dispensers and the initial supplies of chlorine. There are two other promoters who are part of this loan, namely Janet and Carolyne. Tony wants to be a promoter because he believes that the chlorine will allow the community to improve their health.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Tony’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Joseph's Group

Where Joseph lives, his family and his community do not have access to safe drinking water. The community collects their water from Kogare well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. If Kolala had a way to treat their water, they could improve the health of their community, keeping children at school and parents at work.

This is why Joseph is requesting a loan for a chlorine dispenser on behalf of his community. Joseph was elected to represent his community as a volunteer promoter. There are also 3 other promoters from this community, namely Hellen, Abel and Lorna. Joseph is not only representing his community on Kiva, but also volunteers his time to educate the people in  Kolala village on the importance of safe water, and how to use the chlorine dispenser when they come to fetch water at their local water point. The loan will be used for the installation of the dispensers and the initial supplies of chlorine. Joseph wants to be a promoter because he believes that the dispenser will help the community members.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Joseph’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Gaudensia's Group

texts.en:
Gaudensia is 40 years old, has 5 children, and lives in Kajimbo A village in Ndhiwa,Kenya. Gaudensia works as a subsistence farmer for a living. Where Gaudensia lives, her family and her community do not have access to safe drinking water. The community collects their water from Charles pond. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. If Kajimbo A had a way to treat their water, they could improve the health of their community, keeping children at school and parents at work.

This is why Gaudensia is requesting a loan for a chlorine dispenser on behalf of her community. Gaudensia was elected to represent her community as a volunteer promoter. She is not only representing her community on Kiva, but also volunteers her time to educate the people in  Kajimbo A village on the importance of safe water, and how to use the chlorine dispenser when they come to fetch water at Charles pond. There are also other 3 promoters who are also part of this loan: Stella, Michael, and Benta.

The loan will be used for the installation of the dispensers and the initial supplies of chlorine. Gaudensia wants to be a promoter because she believes that the chlorine will kill bacteria and prevent water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Gaudensia’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Benard's Group

texts.en:
Benard is 31 years old, has 6 children, and lives in Kanyatenga B village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Benard works as a peasant farmer for a living. Where Benard lives, his family and his community do not have access to safe drinking water. The community collects their water from the local spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. If Kanyatenga B had a way to treat their water, they could improve the health of their community, keeping children at school and parents at work.

This is why Benard is requesting a loan for a chlorine dispenser on behalf of his community. Benard was elected to represent his community as a volunteer promoter. He is not only representing his community on Kiva, but also volunteers his time to educate the people in  Kanyatenga B village on the importance of safe water, and how to use the chlorine dispenser when they come to fetch water from the spring. The loan will be used for the installation of the dispensers and the initial supplies of chlorine. Bernad and Anderson are the other promoters from Kanyatenga B village who are part of this group loan.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Benard’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Caren's Group

texts.en:
Caren is 26 years old, has 2 children, and lives in Kionyo village Kuria East, Kenya. Caren works as a subsistence farmer for a living. The community of Kionyo village does not have access to clean water. The water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases like cholera and typhoid. Caren is a friendly member of the community and has been elected promoter by her village to help its members obtain safe drinking water.

As a volunteer promoter, Caren represents the community on Kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using a chlorine dispenser. Caren and other promoters in her community need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Caren wants to be a promoter because she believes that the dispenser will make it easy to treat their drinking water through the use of chlorine to give them better health.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Caren’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Angelyne's Group

texts.en:
In Mariri B village in Ndhiwa, Kenya, Angelyne has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Angelyne is a friendly member of the community with 2 children. Angelyne lives with her family in a house made of concrete walls, a concrete floor, and an iron roof.

Mariri B village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from Soko Kodada water source. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Angelyne’s family and the 36 other households in the community need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Angelyne has volunteered to be the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Angelyne volunteered to be the promoter because she wants to help the community improve in terms of health by minimizing cases of water-borne disease. There are also 4 other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Florence, Jane, George and Carolyn.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Angelyne’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

Her community of Rimu B village does not have access to clean water. The water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. Agnes is a friendly member of the community, and has been elected promoter by her village to help its members obtain safe drinking water.

As a volunteer promoter, Agnes represents the community on Kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using a chlorine dispenser. Agnes and 3 other promoters in her community, Mary, Charles, and Carolyne, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Agnes wants to be a promoter because she believes that the chlorine will treat water and prevent water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Agnes’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Monica's Group

texts.en:
Monica is 42 years old, has 4 children, and lives in Nyakwere Kawuor village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Monica works as a peasant farmer for a living. Her community of Nyakwere Kawuor village does not have access to clean water. The water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. Monica is a friendly member of the community, and has been elected promoter by her village to help its members obtain safe drinking water.

As a volunteer promoter, Monica represents the community on Kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using a chlorine dispenser system. Monica and three other promoters in her community need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Monica wants to be a promoter because she believes that the chlorine enables her community have access to safe water so that there will be a reduction on water-borne diseases and improved health.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Monica’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Pamela's Group

texts.en:
Pamela is 36 years old, has 2 children, and lives in Kanguta B village in Ndhiwa sub county, Kenya. Pamela works as a subsistence farmer for a living. Her community of Kanguta B village does not have access to clean water. The water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. Pamela is a friendly member of the community, and has been elected promoter by her village to help its members obtain safe drinking water.

As a volunteer Promoter, Pamela represents the community on Kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using a chlorine dispenser. Pamela and three other promoters in her community including Gaudensia, Robert, and Jesca need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Pamela wants to be a promoter because she believes that the dispenser will help in water treatment.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Pamela’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Sagi

texts.en:
Sagi is married with three children. He is 39 years old. His wife is a housewife. The elder son is 15 years old and goes to ninth class, and the little son is  11 years old and goes to fifth class. Sagi’s daughter is 13 years old and she goes to seventh class. They are IDP (Internally Displaced Persons) from Khalbadjar city, and now live in Baku region. 

Sagi is a taxi driver. He transported passengers between various areas of Baku region. His car was broken. 

Today Sagi needs a loan amount of 1,300 AZN (Azerbaijan New Manat). With this loan he wants to repair his car. 

Sagi is thankful to Kiva organization and lenders for help. In the future he wants help his children have a good education.

loans.use: to repair his car

loans.name: Rosina

texts.en:
Rosina is a 35-year old mother with two children. She runs and operates a small business of selling taro and bananas in her community to earn a living. She hopes to use her profit to expand her business in the near future. 

Rosina has requested a loan to buy taro roots, banana tube, a wheelbarrow, a rake, a shovel, and chemicals to assist her in running the business. She became a member of SPBD in 2014.

loans.use: to buy taro roots, banana tube, a wheelbarrow, a rake, a shovel, and chemicals

loans.name: Sabohat

texts.en: Sabohat was born in 1973 and is a very smart and industrious woman. Sabohat is married and has a child. She lives with her family in the North Tajikistan region. Sabohat has her own business. She has been busy sewing for local people for more than seven years. Sabohat tries to offer her services with high quality so she has regular clients. She always works for the well-being of her daughter. Now, her daughter is a student and she must pay for her daughter’s education. Sabohat is asking for a loan of  $1,700 (USD) to pay her daughter’s tuition. She awaits your support.

loans.use: To pay for tuition

loans.name: Mercedes Estebana

texts.es: Mercedes tiene 47 años de edad y habita en casa propia junto a sus tres hijos. Ella es una mujer  emprendedora que con mucho esfuerzo va sacando adelante a su familia dado que ella es la responsable del hogar ya que su esposo falleció hace un tiempo. Mercedes se gana la vida por medio de la venta de pan dulce y pescado desde hace 12 años y es este negocio el que le permite llevar el sustento a su hogar. Mercedes desea invertir en su negocio en la compra de mayor cantidad de pescado y pan dulce  a fin de aumentar sus ventas e ingresos y poder así dar a su familia mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Mercedes is 47 years old and lives in her own home together with her three children. Mercedes is very entrepreneurial and with much effort is progressing with her family. As her husband died some time ago, Mercedes is entirely responsible for her home. Mercedes has been making a living through the sale of sweet bread and fish for the past 12 years. This business allows her to provide for her family. 

Mercedes wishes to invest in her business by buying the greatest quantity of fish and sweet bread in order to increase her sales and revenue and thus be able to give her family the best life possible.

loans.use: to purchase fish and sweet bread for sale

loans.name: Jose Antonio

texts.es: José de 53 años de edad vive en casa propia con su madre, su esposa y su hija, el posee un vivero ubicado en su lugar de residencia desde hace varios años, comercializa todo tipo de plantas asi como muestra en la fotografia y posee muchos clientes, el esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de abono,tierra negra y mas plantas, para continuar con su trabajo y asi tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
José is 53 years old.  He lives in a house he owns with his mother, his wife, and his daughter.  He had a plant nursery in his home where, for several years, he has sold all types of plants, as shown in the photograph.  He has many customers.  

He is requesting this loan to purchase fertilizer, top soil, and more plants so that he can continue his work and have more income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, top soil, and more plants.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy pigs for his business.

loans.name: Gilda

texts.en:
Gilda is 59 years old and married with eleven children. Gilda works very hard to provide for them.

Gilda runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell. She has been in this business for five years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, soap and other groceries. 

In the future, Gilda would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Lucena is 57 years old and married with five children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Lucena has a fruit vending business in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 15,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase more fruits to sell in her fruit stand.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Lucena has been in this business for 5 years. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more fruits to sell in her fruit stand

loans.name: Jenelyn

texts.en:
Jenelyn is 28 years old and single.

Jenelyn runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell.

Jenelyn has been in this business for two years and sells a variety of items such as canned goods, noodles, soft drinks and other groceries. 

In the future, Jenelyn would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia works hard to support her family. Lucia is married and has a shell craft business in the Philippines.

Lucia requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more raw materials like shells, wire, and nylon thread for her business.

Lucia has been in this business for 15 years now.

Lucia would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more raw materials like shells, wire, and nylon thread for her business

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is a hardworking entrepreneur. For the past 16 years, she has run a business selling Nipa (thatch) roofing in the Philippines. Rebecca earns additional income from farming and selling vegetables. She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. Rebecca has successfully repaid her previous loans.

Rebecca is requesting a 30,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional stocks of Nipa roofing to sell. She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase Nipa roofing to sell

loans.name: Roque Manases

texts.es:
Roque tiene 42 años de edad es casado tiene 3 hijos vive en San Miguel Provincia de Bolivar en la comunidad Salado Chico pertenece a la ventanilla rural San Francisco.

El se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de mais, frejol y papas, solicita el credito para la compra de insumos, fertilizantes agricolas, semillas para asi mejorar la produccion y solventar a su familia, su sueño es mejorar su situacion económica, los desafios a los que se enfrenta es las enfermedades en lo sembrios, en su tiempo libre le gusta dedicarse a su hogar.
texts.en:
Roque is 42 years old. He is married with 3 children. He lives in San Miguel, Bolivar Province, in the community of Salado Chico, belonging to the San Francisco “Window to the Countryside.”

He works in agricultural planting corn, beans and potatoes. He is asking for a loan in order to buy supplies, agricultural fertilizers and seeds, in order to improve his production to support his family. His dream is to improve his financial situation. The challenges he faces is disease to his plants. In his free time he likes to devote himself to the household.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies

loans.name: Luis Amado

texts.es:
Se dedica a la agricultura, ejerce como maestro y  estudia, Luis es una persona multifacética del cual no se limita a lo que puede llegar hacer. Luis además de todo lo que ejerce es padre de familia. Luego de tomar tantas decisiones en su vida escoger Desarrollo social como profesión fue una de las más grandes porque se adecua al perfil profesional de Luis, como docente y persona le interesa el desarrollo de su comunidad. 
Luis solicita el crédito para poder cancelar el curso de titulación que le ayudara a poder optar a otras plazas de trabajo que ayudarían a la economía de su familia, así también realizarse como persona y profesionalmente. Deposita su confianza en el financiamiento que le brindara cumplir sus metas y seguir las otras, así como seguir estudiando y la más próxima salir bien en la defensa de su carrera.
texts.en:
He is a farmer, a teacher, and a student.  Luis is a multifaceted person who is not limited in what he can do; and in addition to everything that he does, Luis is a father. 

Of all the decisions that Luis has made in his life, choosing Social Development as a profession has been one of his best, because it fits his professional profile as a teacher and as a person who is interested in his community’s social development.

Luis is requesting a loan in order to pay for the degree course that will enable him to qualify for other jobs which in turn, would help his family economically and fulfill his personal and professional potential.

He is confident that the loan will provide him with the opportunity to accomplish his goals and pursue others, such as continuing to study, and his next goal, which is to defend his thesis successfully.

loans.use: to pay for a degree course.

loans.name: Gasparin Group

texts.es:
Este grupo está conformado por cuatro mujeres muy emprendedoras (Beksi, Dina, Grethel y Amalia) que se organizaron hace 6 meses, con el propósito de acceder a financiamiento para mejorar sus condiciones de vida, poder cubrir las necesidades básicas de su hogar, asegurar la educación de sus hijos y ampliar sus negocios.

Beksi: Es integrante del grupo solidario, es una mujer joven de 21 años de edad, es casada, tiene 2 hijos: El mayor de 7 años de edad que estudia su primer grado de primaria y un pequeño de 3 años. Su esposo cuenta con una experiencia de 9 años de trabajar como albañil. Ella, desde hace cinco años se dedica a la venta de pescado y mariscos que compra en la comunidad miskita cercana a Bilwi que se llama Lamlaya (agua mansa), de esta manera genera ingresos propios y contribuye con los gastos del hogar y de los estudios de su hijo. Está solicitando préstamo para poder comprar más  mariscos y pescados para vender e incrementar sus ingresos y atender a más personas que demandan este producto que constituye uno de los alimentos básicos en Bilwi. Sueña con llegar a contar con suficiente capital para establecer una pulpería.
texts.en:
This group is made up of 4 very enterprising women (Beksi, Dina, Grethel y Amalia) that got together 6 months ago. Their aim was to obtain financing to improve their living conditions, be able to pay for the basic needs of their household, assure the education of their children and expand their businesses.

Beksi is one member of the communal bank. She is 21 years old, married and has two children. The oldest is 7 years old and studies in Grade 1 in primary school and the youngest is 3 years old. Her husband has 9 years experience working as a bricklayer.

For the past 5 years she has worked selling fish and seafood that she buys in the Miskito village close to Bilwi which is called Lamlaya (gentle waters). In this way she makes her own money and contributes to the household expenses and her child's studies. She is requesting a loan to buy more seafood and fish to sell and increase her income and serve more people who want this product, one of the basic foods of Bilwi. She dreams of having sufficient capital to open a small store.

loans.use: to buy more seafood and fish.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Hello! Meet Rose, 45 years of age, a very hardworking, honest and dedicated farmer who lives in Kiminini, a remote village in Kitale. She is happily married and is blessed with eight adorable children. She has been practicing mixed farming for the last fifteen years and has gained so much experience. 

To afford a decent and comfortable life for her children, she has been selling milk, eggs, and a variety of food crops from her farmland. To make ends meet and make extra cash, she has also been engaging in another small personal business. 

The Kitale area is very populated, and demand for poultry products and eggs is very high. Like many farmers from her region, she finds poultry farming very enjoyable, and she stated that the most enjoyable part about poultry farming is “the increased profits I enjoy.” Her biggest challenge, however, is meeting the demand that is really high. She lacks funds to increase her poultry farming, and so she is seeking a loan of 65,000 KES (Kenyan shillings) to buy poultry. 

Being a woman, accessing funds is very challenging, but through institutions such as Juhudi Kilimo via Kiva, she feels relieved knowing that her dream will be achieved, and she will be able to buy more poultry. Through the loan, she will sell eggs and poultry products to her neighbors and to the local market, and this will translate to increased profit margins and an improved income level. 

Being a visionary woman, she intends to accumulate more profits and increase her poultry market to other markets; this will increase her income and improve her living conditions. The extra income she will get will be used to fully repay the loan and permanently change her living conditions, as well as to secure the future of her school-going children.

Help Rose with a loan today!

loans.use: To buy poultry

loans.name: Nongkhun Group

texts.en:
Vieng's village takes water from wells and from the local streams. Some people in the village, including Vieng’s, are able to buy bottled water. The water from natural sources in this area is dirty and unsuitable for drinking without treatment. The nearby villages also suffer from dirty and unsafe drinking water.

Vieng is excited that she, like her group members, was able to purchase a water filter. Most families report a threefold reduction in diarrhea after they begin using the filter; this is because the filter removes bacteria and other water-borne diseases.

The water filter also increases disposable income for users like Vieng due to the decreased cost of purchasing charcoal, by decreasing time spent foraging for wood, and decreasing the amount of money used to purchase bottled water. The filter is guaranteed for two years, though most find the filter works for three-five years.

loans.use: to purchase a TerraClear water filter so she can have access to safe drinking water.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a business selling charcoal and firewood in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell to her customers for her charcoal and firewood business.

Lydia has been in this business for five years. Lydia earns additional income from food vending.

Lydia has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more firewood and charcoal to sell to her customers

loans.name: Maendeleo Riz Group

texts.fr: Incité par ses parents qui lui ont appris que l'agriculture est une richesse, Kiza a commencé à cultiver à l'âge de 18 ans. Pour renforcer sa capacité financière, il sollicite ce crédit afin de payer la main d'oeuvre et acheter l'engrais. Ce qui lui plait dans cette activité est la quantité de récolte obtenue lui permettant de répondre aux besoins familiaux. Il souhaite dans l'avenir améliorer sa production, ses conditions sociales et garder les bonnes relations avec Paidek. Il est président du groupe MAENDELEO RIZ et sur la photo il tient un carnet rose.
texts.en:
Encouraged by his parents, who explained to him that working in agriculture was a profitable enterprise, Kiza started growing crops at the age of eighteen years old. 

Kiza has requested this loan in order to strengthen his financial situation, and be able to buy fertilizer and pay for labour costs.  He is particularly pleased with the quantity of food that he harvests, and happy that he can provide for the needs of his family.

In the future, Kiza wants to increase his production levels, improve his social condition and maintain a good relationship with the field partner, Paidek.  He is the president of the 'Maendeleo Riz' Group, and is seen in the photo holding his pink registration document.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pay for labour for weeding and harvesting for his agriculture business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to pay labour costs for weeding and buy fertilizer for his agriculture business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pay for labour for weeding and harvesting for his agriculture business.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
As a married parent of six children, Gina works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling vitamins and liniments.  Gina is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF to purchase an additional fishing net for her fishing business.

She successfully repaid her previous loan, and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

Gina has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase an additional fishing net

loans.name: Andrew's Group

texts.en:
Andrew is 53 years old, has 7 children, and lives in Ratanga village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Andrew works as a subsistence farmer for a living. Where Andrew lives, his family and his community do not have access to safe drinking water. The community collects their water from Ndiege borehole. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. If Ratanga villagers had a way to treat their water, they could improve the health of their community, keeping children at school and parents at work.

This is why Andrew is requesting a loan for a chlorine dispenser on behalf of his community. There is also another promoter who is part of this loan called Hellen. Andrew was elected to represent his community as a volunteer promoter. He is not only representing his community on Kiva, but also volunteers his time to educate the people in  Ratanga village on the importance of safe water, and how to use the chlorine dispenser when they come to fetch water at their local water point. The loan will be used for the installation of the dispensers and the initial supplies of chlorine. Andrew wants to be a promoter because he believes that the dispenser will prevent water-borne diseases and kill germs in the water.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Andrew’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Carolyne's Group

texts.en:
Carolyne is 33 years old, has 6 children, and lives in Rapedhi village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Carolyne is a businesswoman. Her community of Rapedhi village does not have access to clean water. The water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. Carolyne is a friendly member of the community, and has been elected promoter by her village to help its members to obtain safe drinking water.

As a volunteer promoter, Carolyne represents the community on Kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using the chlorine dispenser. Carolyne and 3 other promoters in her community, Millicent, Carolyn, and Jane need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Carolyne wants to be a promoter because she  believes that the chlorine kills germs in water, making it safe for drinking, and hence prevents water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Carolyne’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To improve health and productivity by increasing access to safe drinking water through chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en:
Rose is 21 years old, and lives in Atieli A village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Rose works as a business owner for a living. Where Rose lives, her family and her community do not have access to safe drinking water. The community collects their water from Kagwonyo spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. If Atieli A village had a way to treat their water, they could improve the health of their community, keeping children at school and parents at work.

This is why Rose is requesting a loan for a chlorine dispenser on behalf of her community. Rose was elected to represent his community as a volunteer promoter. She is not only representing her community on Kiva, but also volunteers her time to educate the people in  Atieli A village on the importance of safe water, and how to use the chlorine dispenser when they come to fetch water at Kagwonyo spring. The loan will be used for the installation of the dispensers and the initial supplies of chlorine. Rose wants to be a promoter because she believes that the dispenser helps prevent water-borne diseases. 

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Rose’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Mariela De Fatima

texts.es: Mariela nació en el año 1974, ella habita en la comunidad de el Sardinal. Mariela tiene 4 hijos quienes asisten a la escuela de la comunidad. Mariela trabaja en agricultura con sus hijos, ella siembra granos basicos y café lo que representa su mayor fuente de ingresos. En la comunidad de El Sardinal no hay acceso a la energía electrica, es por eso que Mariela desea adquirir un pequeño sistema solar para poder brindar luz a su familia, y de esa manera dejar de usar el candil para iluminarse.
texts.en: Mariela was born in 1974 and lives in the community of El Sardinal. Mariela has 4 children who attend school in the community. Mariela works in agriculture with her children, planting basic grains and coffee which is their main source of income. In the community of El Sardinal, there is no access to electric power, that is why Mariela would like to purchase a small solar power system to bring light to her family, and thus stop using oil lamps to illuminate her home.

loans.use: to buy a solar power system.

loans.name: Joyce's Group

texts.en:
Joyce lives in a home with concrete walls, a dirt floor, and an iron roof in Kamlungo A village in Ndhiwa, Kenya with her family which includes 4 children. The community of Kamlungo A village collects their drinking water from Kombewa spring because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Kamlungo A’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source, where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. In Kamlungo A, 25 households will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe water. Joyce has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter, who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy. There are 2 other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Daisy and Kennedy.

Kamlungo A village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. Joyce believes that by having safe water her community will be free from water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Joyce’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Christy

texts.en:
As a married mother of three children, Christy works hard to support her family.

She has a fish vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending.  Christy is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF in order to buy more fish to sell to customers.

Christy has been sustaining her business activities through her past 10 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en:
Rose is 36 years old, has 6 children, and lives in Rabare C village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Rose works as a subsistence farmer for a living. Her community of Rabare C village does not have access to clean water. The water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. Rose is a friendly member of the community, and has been elected promoter by her village to help its members obtain safe drinking water.

As a volunteer promoter, Rose represents the community on Kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using the chlorine dispenser. Rose and 2 other promoters in her community, Mary and Evalyn, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Rose wants to be a promoter because she believes that when her community members take safe water they will not have a problem with water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Rose’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Paul's Group

texts.en:
Paul is 58 years old, has 6 children, and lives in Nyamiencho village in Kuria East, Kenya. Nyamiencho village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from Remaroa well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Paul’s community may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Paul works as a subsistence farmer, but has also volunteered his time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables his community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Paul and 3 other promoters in his community, Susan, Anjeline, and Thomas need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Paul will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Paul wants to be a promoter because he believes that the dispenser will help to fight water-borne diseases and they will therefore have better health.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Paul’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Eunice's Group

texts.en:
Eunice is 32 years old, has 2 children, and lives in Kasudi village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Kasudi village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from Karangoma spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Eunice and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Eunice works as a peasant farmer, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Eunice and 2 other promoters in her community,  Mary and Isdora need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Eunice will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Eunice wants to be a promoter because she believes that the dispenser will prevent waterborne diseases in the community.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Eunice’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Jane's Group

texts.en:
In Koyier Upper village in Ndhiwa, Kenya, Jane has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Jane is a friendly member of the community with 3 children. Jane lives with her family in a house made of concrete walls, a concrete floor, and an iron roof.

Koyier Upper village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a local water source. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Jane’s family and the 15 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Jane has volunteered to be the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Jane volunteered to be the promoter because she wants to help the community to prevent sickness. There are also one other volunteer promoter from the surrounding community who is part of this group loan; he is called Hesbon.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Jane’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Hellen's Group

texts.en:
Hellen is 51 years old, has 5 children, and lives in Karateng village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Hellen works as a peasant farmer for a living. Her community of Karateng village does not have access to clean water. The water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. Hellen is a friendly member of the community, and has been elected promoter by her village to help its members obtain safe drinking water.

As a volunteer promoter, Hellen represents the community on Kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using the chlorine dispenser. Hellen and 4 other promoters in her community, including Pamella, Monica, Lilian, and Penina need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Nyaite’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

Where Joseph lives, his  community do not have access to safe drinking water. The community collects their water from Joanes well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. If Kugitimo B had a way to treat their drinking water, they could improve the health of their community, keeping children at school and parents at work.

This is why Joseph is requesting a loan for a chlorine dispenser on behalf of his community. Joseph was elected to represent his community as a volunteer promoter. He is not only representing his community on Kiva, but also volunteers his time to educate the people in  Kugitimo B village on the importance of safe drinking water and how to use the chlorine dispenser when they come to fetch water at Joanes well. The loan will be used for the installation of the dispensers and the initial supplies of chlorine. Joseph wants to be a promoter because he believes that the dispenser will help reduce water-borne diseases caused by contaminated water.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Joseph’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.name: Penina's Group

texts.en:
Penina lives in a home with mud walls, a dirt floor and an iron roof in Mosaro village in Kuria East, Kenya with her family which includes 4 children. The community of Mosaro village collects their drinking water from a local well because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases often making Mosaro’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser program offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination.  Community of Mosaro will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe water. Penina has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy. There are 4 other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan.

Penina’s community needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. Penina believes that the dispenser will help her community stay healthy. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Penina’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Sina

texts.en:
Sina is a 61-year-old mother with five children. For more than two years, she has owned and operated a general store in her village to earn a living. Sina joined SPBD in 2012.

Sina is requesting a loan to buy sacks of sugar, rice, and flour as well as a box of tinned fish for her store. She will use the profit from her loan to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy sacks of sugar, rice, and flour as well as a box of tinned fish

loans.name: Wilson Alexander

texts.es:
Wilson  tiene 40 años, viudo con dos hijas menores de edad quienes aún asisten en el colegio, a pesar de las circunstancias Wilson como todo un hombre emprendedor trabaja con su moto taxi  día tras día para dar una mejor calidad de vida a sus dos hijas. El  deseo de Wilson es darles a sus hijas estudios superiores. El crédito lo invertirá en comprar materiales de construcción: calamina, cemento para brindarles un mejor ambiente de estudios a sus hijas.
Está agradecido por el apoyo recibido por parte de los inversionistas Kiva
texts.en:
Wilson, 40, is a widower with two young daughters who are still at school. Despite Wilson's circumstances, Wilson is hard working man, working with his motorbike taxi every day to give his daughters a better quality of life. Wilson wants to send his daughters to college. The loan he is asking for is to buy construction materials: corrugated iron and cement to provide a better learning environment for his daughters.
He is grateful for all the help received from Kiva investors.

loans.use: to buy construction materials (corrugated iron and cement).

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies for his pineapple farm.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon is 55 years old and widowed with five children. Three of her children are in school. For the past seven years, Corazon has been a vegetable farmer in the Philippines. She also earns additional income from fattening pigs. 

Corazon is requesting an 8,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies. She is working tirelessly toward attaining her dream of saving enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and farm supplies

loans.name: Harun

texts.en: Harun is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, he would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to provide for his immediate cash needs. With his loan and Babban Gona’s support, Harun can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Harun is looking to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family. He hopes to make more money for himself and his family in the future.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing for his family and eliminate the pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita is 55 years old and married with seven children who are all in school. For 20 years, she has been a sugarcane farmer in the Philippines. Juanita also earns additional income from running a general store. 

Juanita is requesting an 11,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies. She is working tirelessly toward attaining her dream of saving enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and farm supplies

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
As a married mother of six children, Marlyn works hard to support her family.

She has a fish vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising livestock. Marlyn is borrowing 10,000 PHP through NWTF in order to buy more fish to sell to customers.

Marlyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past nine loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay laborers and to purchase cement, sand, and bricks.

loans.name: Marynor

texts.en:
Marynor is 40 years old and married. Her husband is a farmer and they manage a drugstore near a private hospital. She has been operating her store for six years. She hires and pay staff who help her in the store. 

Marynor requested a loan for 50,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase boxes of medicines and multivitamins to sell. She hopes to continue selling good products and affordable medicines. She also hopes to achieve financial stability.

loans.use: to purchase boxes of medicines and multivitamins to sell

loans.name: Tujitume Group

texts.en:
Bupe, who is in her mid-30s, is married with four children who are still in school. She has been running two businesses, food vending and a grocery store, for two years now. She works from 6:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.  

This will be Bupe's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She will use this loan to increase her mama lishe (food vending) stock and to buy drinks for the grocery store.  She dreams of building her own shop so she can stop renting.

Bupe will share this loan with her loan group "Tujitume" which consists of six members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to increase her mama lishe (food vending) stock and to buy drinks for the grocery store.

loans.name: Nazira

texts.en: Nazira was born in 1979 and is single with no children. She lives alone. Nazira is a business lady.who has run her own business buying and selling clothes for more than five years. Nazira buys clothing for women, children and men in bulk, and sells the clothes retail in a local market. Her working day usually begins early in the morning. She works hard every day to earn a living. She has a kind heart and always helps needy people. Nazira plans to widen the assortment of her goods and, in this way, attract more customers. She is asking for a loan of 7,500 TJS to buy clothes for her business. She awaits your support.

loans.use: To buy clothes to widen the assortment of her goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy corn, firewood, butter, cheese curd, etc., for her business.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles sells fruits in Thika town and has been running this business for 13 years. He is 37 years old, married, and together with his spouse, they have been blessed with two children. 

Charles will use this loan to buy more stocks of mangoes and oranges to sell. He will use the anticipated profits to improve his business. 

This is his first loan from VisionFund Kenya and his future hopes are to expand his fruit-selling business and to live a happy life with his family.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of fruits to sell.

loans.name: Ma. Gina

texts.en:
Ma. Gina is a married 35-year-old mother of one child, who is in school. Ma. Gina is a very hard-working entrepreneur who owns a pet shop business in the Philippines. Ma. Gina requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional fish, fish food and other materials for her business.

Ma. Gina has been in this business for six years. Ma. Gina would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish, fish food and other materials for her pet shop business.

loans.name: Marietta

texts.en:
Marietta is 59 years old and married with seven children.

Marietta works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell.

Marietta has borrowed and repaid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 14 years and also earns income from pig fattening.

Marietta aspires to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more poultry

loans.name: Felomina

texts.en:
Felomina is 42 years old and married, with five children, three of whom are in school. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. 

Felomina is borrowing PHP 10,000 through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) in order to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Felomina has been raising pigs for three years and also earns additional income from a general store. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream, to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora is 44 years old and married with three children, one in school.

Leonora works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell.

Leonora has borrowed and repaid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for four years and also earns an income from pig fattening.

Leonora aspires to save enough money to support the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena is 48 years old and married with four children, two in school.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Nena is borrowing PHP 13,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Nena has been raising pigs for 20 years and earns additional income from buying and selling peanuts.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream of saving enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 43 years old and married with six children, four in school.

Erlinda works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell.

Erlinda has borrowed and repaid 17 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 14 years and also earns an income from food vending.

Erlinda aspires to save enough money to build a restaurant at the public market.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Reina Elizabeth

texts.es:
Reina, de 34 años de edad, es ama de casa y su nivel de estudio fue hasta el segundo grado, no siguió estudiando porque, sus padres no tenían los recursos económicos suficientes para que ella continuara; está acompañada, pero no tienen hijos aun, su compañero de vida se dedica a la agricultura, mientras que Reina, se dedica a la venta de ropa desde hace 5 años.

Reina, aprendió este trabajo debido a la situación económica que tenia y para ayudarle a su esposo en los gastos del hogar.- Reina, vende ropa en los alrededores de su comunidad y su horario es de 8:00 a.m. a 5:00 p.m. todos los días.

El préstamo que está solicitando en credicampo es para comprar más ropa y así poder ofrecerles un poco más de productos a sus clientes y lograr de ésta manera, tener un poco más de ingresos para ayudar más en los gastos de su hogar y poder pagar el préstamo adquirido sin ningún inconveniente.
